awd_titl_txt: Translating a Video-based Model of Teacher Professional Development to an Online Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
Improving the quality of teaching is essential to improving student outcomes. But what are the most effective ways to support teachers' professional development?  BSCS Science Learning and the University of Minnesota STEM Education Program Area explore this question by adapting an effective teacher professional development model -- that meets face-to-face in real-time -- to an online approach. A defining feature of the Science Teachers Learning from Lesson Analysis (STeLLA) Professional Development program is its use of videos of classroom instruction and examples of student work to promote teacher learning. Skilled facilitators guide teachers' analysis and discussion of other teachers' work; then, teachers begin to apply the analytical techniques they have learned to their own teaching. Adapting the STeLLA program to an online learning model is important because it can reach a broader and more diverse audience such as teachers working in rural school districts and underserved communities. To further promote the reach of STeLLA, the online version of STeLLA will engage and prepare teacher leaders to support their peers' engagement and understanding. 

The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects. Guided by theories of situated cognition and cognitive apprenticeship this project focuses on two questions: How can the STeLLA professional development model be adapted to an online environment? and Does participation in the online model show meaningful teacher and student outcomes related to science teaching and learning? Challenges related to adaptation include understanding the duration and intensity of teacher engagement, the quality of their science content learning experiences, and how teacher learning is scaffolded across the online and traditional model. The project will unfold in two phases. Phase 1 uses a design-based research approach to rapidly enact, test, and revise online program components while remaining true to the design principles underlying the traditional STeLLA PD program. Phase 2 uses a quasi-experimental approach to test STeLLA Online's influence on teacher content knowledge, pedagogical content knowledge, practice and on upper elementary student science achievement. Comparisons will be made between STeLLA Online, face-to-face STeLLA, and a traditional professional development program that emphasizes deepening content knowledge only. This comparison leverages data from a previously-completed cluster randomized trial of STeLLA funded by the NSF.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
Effective professional learning (PL) for elementary science teachers should enhance the achievement of their science students. Some recent video-based analysis-of-practice PL models have evidence of efficacy, but these face-to-face PL models are often expensive and largely inaccessible to teachers in underfunded and rural districts. We designed and examined the impact of a fully online version of a face-to-face PL model with previously demonstrated efficacy. In a quasi-experimental study reaching teachers and students in 18 states conducted between 2020 and 2022 (20 schools, 26 teachers, and 472 students) using comparison data from a single state (37 schools, 59 teachers, and 1533 students collected in a previous study conducted between 2011 and 2013), we found no significant difference between the face-to-face and online versions of the video-based PL (p = .162).  

     Our translation of the face-to-face, analysis-of-classroom practice PL into a fully online version required that we attend carefully to the design principles of the original model. We took special care to design and iterate asynchronous learning experiences that 1) maximized sense-making opportunities for teachers in both pedagogical and science learning; 2) ensured that we gradually built communities of trust within the online PL environment; 3) provided rich information about teachers' initial understandings to the facilitators. Each four-hour asynchronous module was followed by a two-hour synchronous session. Participants had time to think, facilitators had time to review and consider initial asynchronous responses, and the valuable synchronous session time (held over video conferencing software) was used to work with teachers to build agreement and understanding over more complex ideas that we found were confusing for teachers in each asynchronous session.

     Our findings demonstrate that it is possible to transform complex, intensive face-to-face PL models to online experiences, increasing accessibility while maintaining much of the impact of the original face-to-face models.


Last Modified: 01/02/2024
Modified by: Molly A Stuhlsatz
